comment_body.0:
Location: SF Bay Area

Price range: 40k

Lease or Buy: Either

New or used: Either

Type of vehicle: Crossover/SUV/Wagon

Must haves: Plug in hybrid, AWD/4x4

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): auto

Intended use: Daily driver

Vehicles you've already considered: Subaru Crosstrek

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Yes

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: I'm suddenly driving a lot as work goes back to in-person and racking up ~$450 in gas bills in my 2016 Tacoma every month. I need to fix that, so looking for a plug in hybrid that I can use to get to and from work on electric mode every day, but I want the gas option so that I can get out to the mountains on weekends. It would be a big plus to be able to sleep in the back and I need to be able to haul quite a bit of outdoor gear (insert subaru owner meme). Thank you in advance!
comment_body.1: I'm down to two options, a 2021 Rav4 XLE Premium AWD or a 2021 Chevy Trailblaizer RS AWD. I am having a heck of a time deciding. The Rav4 is slightly higher priced, but as a current Toyota owner I enjoy the reliability. I appreciate your thoughts on this!
comment_body.2:
made the same comment last week, think I need to cast as wide a net as possible

Location: SLC, Ut

Price range: Max $10k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: I love the idea of a luxury/sports sedan but pretty much anything is on the table. I really don’t care for SUVs or crossovers but I’m sure the right one could sway me

Must haves: Reliability has to be priority #1 but I would love something with nice driving dynamics and a little bit of lower-end torque for city driving

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual preferred but not mandatory. I would rather get something a little sporty with an auto than a boring stick

Intended use: Daily + Weekend fun car

Vehicles you've already considered: miata, infiniti g35/37, volvo s60, ford taurus, subaru wrx, mini cooper

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Super basic things like battery and oil are manageable but I have very little in the way of tools and know-how

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: Currently driving a turbo’d ‘94 miata and love it to death. Would absolutely drive it to the grave but the cost of maintaining a modded vehicle are proving to be steeper than I can accommodate. The original owner got forged rods and pins, turbo, AEM series 2 ecu, suspension, clutch, exhaust all aftermarket and I’m sure a few others things I’m forgetting but it ended up sitting in a shed for almost a decade. Been getting it back into shape and dailying it over the last 2 years but I think I have to accept the fact that paying a shop for diagnostics, parts and labor on a modded vehicle everytime something rusts out isn’t sustainable.

I know nothing in my price range is going to compete with this car, especially with the markets as they are but I have to get something with at least a little bit of fun factor that I can in good conscience show my wife to make it easier to let go of my current car. We’re considering selling mine now while the market is crazy and waiting a few months to see if it cools down at all, should we have any reason to believe used cars are going to be closer to sane prices in 6 months?
comment_body.4:

Intended use: Mainly highway and country road driving but sometimes (max once per week) driving in the city

Vehicles you've already considered: skoda fabia, hyundai i20 and i10, seat ibiza, opel corsa (but just based on some short research)

Is this your 1st vehicle: kind of (my first one had a gearbox failure after ~2000 miles)

Do you need a Warranty: no

Additional Notes: I mainly want to get from A to B. The car should be comfortable to drive with cruise control and it should have the power to overtake slow drivers if required. As stated it will be mainly used on higways and therefore it should be capable to handle the fuel consumption at that speed.

After all, I really don't care about the car expect for it beeing able to transport me and not beeing to expensive in acquirement, fuel and reparation costs. Thanks for your recommendations!

comment_body.10:
(anything left out is something I don't know yet and is part of why I'm asking, or something I don't care about)

Location: New England region, USA
Price range: Max $40k, but the cheaper the better since every dollar spent has to come out of my "house down-payment" fund
Lease or Buy: Buy
Must haves:
- Decent for making long trips (8+ hours) into relatively remote areas that sometimes include dirt/gravel roads.
- Sufficient storage space for a decent amount of stuff - construction supplies, art projects, and group camping trips are all common enough. Doesn't need to all be internal, but I don't have space to keep a trailer right now either.
- Safe enough for driving a kid on the verge of growing out of a carseat to visit his grandparents.
Intended use: Mostly shopping trips around town once or twice a week with longer trips (2+ hours) a few times a month. Don't need it for commuting. Will probably have some fun customizing the usable/cosmetic bits but I don't mess with the mechanical parts.
Is this your 1st vehicle: No, last vehicle was a 2001 Toyota Camry Do you need a Warranty: No
Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes
Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:
A deer totaled my last car and it would be easy enough to get another similar one since it worked... fine. But I figure I'll treat this as an opportunity to widen my horizons and maybe consider some stuff I normally wouldn't think of or wouldn't normally own. I've been looking at everything brand new electric cars to used scooters and trying to narrow down what I actually want, and I'm actually thinking its pointing in the direction of a... van? That might just be bias, though, since my favorite vehicle I ever owned was my old Chevy G20 conversion, but I haven't thought about or looked at vans in almost two decades now. I've just got nostalgia for carrying around theatre supplies and sitting on the roof drinking with the girlfriend as we watch the sun go down. And nostalgia... probably isn't the best reason to buy a specific vehicle (or is it?) so maybe there's something else that would work better or that could do what I needed while being more affordable.

I don't drive all that much, maybe once or twice a week to get into the city or get some groceries, but it would be nice to switch to something that would give me more room for construction supply runs and for taking more supplies/projects to the arts festivals and other events I like to go to instead of having to constantly decide "well, I can't fit it all so I guess I'll have to cut this stuff out". I'll probably drive it into the ground, whatever it will be, so I don't really have to worry about the resale value when I inevitable give it a shitty custom paintjob or something.

comment_body.26:
Loc: Vancouver

Price range: 5k

Buy

Used

Manual

Sedan/hatchback/compact/subcompact

Pleasure use

5th vehicle

Can do minor work

Cannot do major work

Additional info:

Manual, 67000 km, looks like it's in really good condition, has a collectors edition license plate and some original parts.

Previous owner replaced timing belt, clutch and ignition relating parts.After I bought, I replaced suspension component such as shock/struts, control arm bushing, sway bar bushings, etc.. It comes with extra parts such as spark plugs, distributor cap/rotor, and few other

I'm just learning standard and was looking for something to drive around on. This isn't going to be a work or daily use vehicle. I came across this and it looked kind of cool, I like the 90s look because my first car was a 91 Accord.

I'm basically just getting an interest in cars as a hobby. It's a collector by local insurance standards, it needs to be to get those plates. I just think it's a cool old car. Feels like the clock is ticking to drive a roadworthy 90s car.

I've read some kind of sketchy things about Hyundai's early cars, especially the Excel's 80's models but I've also heard some of it was ironed out by the later models. reading some old reviews some people absolutely love the car but it could be rose tinted glasses. Others say it had all kinds of problems.

It looks like it was well looked after and they have a google doc of all the work they've done on it. But I still feel on the fence about it because I feel like I will have a hard time re-selling it in the future. But it looks really cool.

I was going to call and ask a few questions too, the ads been up for over a week so I think they might have a hard time finding a buyer so I thought I'd get a second opinion. Most people I've asked think it's a meh decision. Is there anything specific questions I should maybe ask?

Open to other ideas or advice for cars in the 90s too.

comment_body.29:
Bedfordshire, England, UK.

£5000 is a pretty hard limit, can maybe stretch a hundred or two over that for something really nice.

Looking to buy outright, no finance or leasing, so I am of course looking for used.

Ideally a hatchback or sedan (if sedan isn't the American for saloon... I mean saloon, sorry).

Must have manual transmission, also I'm a young guy and insurance is compulsory here so nothing too hugely powerful or ridiculous (although through some accidental genius that I'll explain below I can get something decent), but I am looking for something pretty fun that I'm not gunna get bored of after a few months - a year. Also something with pretty decent reliability would be great.

This'll be my daily driver, and kind of first car. I'm perfectly happy to do minor work myself, and some more major stuff but anything too bad or complicated and it'll go to the garage which I'm fine with, my best friend was a mechanic for 5 years and he has a lot of friends in that industry still that can get things sorted for not much more than the price of the part, £50 and a can of irn bru.

So the two cars I've mainly been looking at right now are a 2013 ford fiesta 1.0 ecoboost, and a 2008 BMW 320i, both with under 70k miles on the clock. They are the same for me to insure, because I've actually had a car insured on provisional license racking up some nice no claims bonus for the last 2 years that for a few reasons I couldn't pass my test and drive properly until now (theory test booked, shortly after will be the practical so next 6-8 months realistically), and that car has blown up. Also the ecoboost has a turbo which immediately makes it more expensive to insure, I got a lil dinger tucked away in my pants which increases insurance, and I'm 20 which means that a lot of people my age have got fiestas and smashed the tits off them which increases insurance for fiestas.

For the last while I've been paying provisional insurance and tax on the car I wasn't driving, plus a monthly bus ticket. With the insurance and tax of each car they equal about the same as that cost I'll only be worse off by the cost of petrol, and I'll only drive 100-120 miles a week with the very rare longer journey so that's not too much of a worry either.

Obviously I'll be paying quite a bit more for petrol in the bmw, and it is quite a bit bigger so actually learning to drive and park it will be a tad more difficult to start but I'm not too worried about that. The fiesta seems like the smarter choice on the surface because it's smaller, I don't have to pay tax on it, it'll only sip at fuel and it's a fair bit newer, also it's a ford and they're everywhere so parts will be cheaper. However, I want this car to last for the next 5-10 years with it being looked after properly, and that little 1L fiesta engine will begin to feel quite slow and boring, also the bmw is rwd which adds to the fun and it's also just much prettier than the fiesta, plus that famous German reliability.

I've found a few options for each that are withing budget, less than 75k miles and all seem fairly well looked after, there's one 320i that I'm leaning most towards because it comes with Bluetooth and satnav options selected and I just prefer the bmw, but it'll depend on how it is in person and if there's anything wrong with it really.

Mostly what I'm asking for is other options that'll fit what I'm looking for really, the fun factor is fairly important to me (although I'll be fairly easily impressed coming from a blown up Punto), reliability, and ideally not crazy insurance (petrol turbos probably best avoided in most cases but I'll be happy to get a quote for anything). Also, opinions on what you'd do in this situation.

As a side note, I am seriously tempted by an mx5, but the two seats would be an issue for me, but at the same time mx5, but I will often be ferrying a few people around at a time so I really can't lol.

Any help is appreciated.

comment_body.35:
Location: Southeast (Georgia)

Price range: $40k - $70k MSRP ($400 - $900 / mo lease)

New or used: New

Type of vehicle: Crossover / Small SUV

Must haves: Smooth ride (for potholes), back seat room (for rear-facing car seat)

Wants: "Quick" acceleration (>6s 0-60, ideally less), traffic jam assist down to a stop, tech features (e.g., wireless Apple CarPlay / Android Auto, HUD)

Intended use: Family car / daily driver

Vehicles you've already considered:

  • BMW X3 M40i: In an ideal world, this would be the car that I get and it seems to tick all of the boxes that I'm looking for. Unfortunately it's on the higher end of my price range and the rear seat room seems small compared to other crossovers (RWD architecture).
  • Audi Q5 55e: Less flashy than the BMW, but seems to be well built and well put together. Furthermore, it qualifies for the federal tax credits which should roll into the lease discount, making for a much more attractive lease price (i.e., $500-700 vs. $750-900 for the BMW).
  • Acura RDX: At a lower price point, but seems to have a lot of the features that I'm interested in, though with a much less interesting powertrain. With the announcement of the 2022 features, it seems they've focused heavily on ride quality and NVH, so hoping that will bring it in line with the German alternatives.
  • Genesis GV70: Seemed like a good bargain over the Germans, while offering more technology. However, with the MSRP markups and having to deal with Hyundai dealerships, I would rather go with the BMW / Audi at this price point.
  • Hyundai Tucson: On paper seems to have a ton of rear legroom and cargo space, while also being much more affordable as it isn't luxury. That being said, all of the reviews I've seen have praised its ride quality and insulation so I'm curious if it could fit my needs better than the luxury / near-luxury cars. The most challenging part will be dealing with a Hyundai dealership.

Anything else I should be considering, or out of these options, is there one that stands out as a better lease deal?

comment_body.45:
A very big thank you in advance to all who reply in helping guide my decision.

Location: California soon to be NYC Tristate areaPrice range: 3-5k down, goal monthly payment under 500/moLease or Buy: Buy - We'd go over yearly miles for a leaseNew or used: Either orType of vehicle: (Truck, Car, Sports Car, Sedan, Crossover, SUV, Racecar, Luxury etc.)SUV or Crossover - must have AWD. Trying to decide if EV is appropriate and affordable for us, or a Plug-in Hybrid is worth it. Home charging possible.Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): AutomaticIntended use: Everyday daily driver. We will have 1 family car that will be split between my spouse and I. Spouse works remotely from home and I go in 2 very long days a week, with a possible third day. We also will check in on our aging parents frequently, who live about 60 miles each way in opposite directions - with some city/urban driving involved.Vehicles you've already considered: VW id4, Ford Mustang Mach E, Rav4 Prime, Subaru Partial Zero Emission Vehicle OutbackIs this your 1st vehicle:

No - I've had a 2011 Corolla that is a lemon (bought 2013). Starting in 2017, I've had to put about 2k a year in repairs on avg: transmissions leaks, engine needed resealing twice, all power locks went out - twice, powertrain issues while thankfully under warranty. All with only 75k miles in 10 years, granted it is city driving with a lot of stop and go.

Do you need a Warranty: Hard yes.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:

We can only afford 1 car, as our second car will be left in CA on a military base for my spouse to use when he comes out every other month for 2 weeks military obligations. We did the math and a car rental or now expensive Lyft is way more costly, and his Camry is far more reliable than my paid off lemon of a Corolla.

We want an SUV because we like to go to remote areas for family camping and want a vehicle capable of that.

We would love to take advantage of the EV rebates (and get a start on an EV before the rebates go away in a decade as EV become mainstream), but unsure if possible for an affordable SUV with long range battery capabilities. We are unsure if the cost to maintain a plug-in hybrid is worth it, and seen some battery complaints on the Rav4 Prime.

A lease seemed ideal because of minimal need for repairs right off the bat but the miles would slaughter us.

Type of vehicle: Sedan (Luxury or Sport), Hatchback, maybe Crossover

Desired transmission: Dream of a manual but I know all hybrids are automatic.

Intended use: Weekend trips (taking it for hiking/camping), daily driver.

Vehicles you've already considered: Hyundai Sonata Hybrid, Honda Accord Hybrid, Honda Insight Hybrid, Volkswagen GTI

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Not yet, but would want to learn.

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: I'm looking for a fuel efficient and comfortable car that won't need serious work or replacing for a long time. I'd prefer the driving experience to be enjoyable as well if possible, though I know hybrids in my price range don't have great performance.
